Last night I had a rather... interesting accident with a spaceplane and had to bring her down immediately. Jersey Kerman, trooper and iron-man pilot, bravely got the stricken craft about 80km away from the KSP before running out of jet fuel and having to set down in the foothills of that mountain range. It happened too fast; either the starboard landing gear gave way or the starboard wing tip dug itself in, but the bird disassembled itself in a long, slow crash that left no debris to recover.

But Jersey wasn't dead. He wasn't reported killed in the F3 report. And when I returned to the Space Centre he was listed as "Missing".

Okay... what just happened? Do I expect Jersey to walk back through 80km of wilderness in a few days, or what?

-- Steve

I agree that the whole concept of kerbals "missing in action" only to appear later does cheapen the whole kerbal recruitment system. There is literally no reason to hire kerbals once you have enough to run your missions. If they die they just pop back up in your available kerbals reserve as soon as you reload the game, or not long thereafter.

Perhaps this will be rectified for career mode.
I'm pretty sure if you go into the save config there's a crew permadeath flag that's disabled by default.

I like to think of the new end flight as the vessel going permanently missing, rather than being destroyed, so MIA makes sense there.

By default, lost kerbals are marked as MIA, and re-appear after a long time. In the settings file, there's a permadeath line, which if sets true makes Kerbals go KIA and never re-appear.

I've only lost one in my space program so far, thankfully.
